1.\nOne day, night will come to these mountains.
2.\nOur days of idle pleasure winnow down; their sweetness doubles as their numbers dwindle.
3.\nThe day draws back, the time of struggle ebbs. Sun-scarred relics lie about the land.
4.\nHere and there an oracle who sees the night ahead: the rude glimmer of it, tucked into the corners of our sky.
5.\nHere, in the winding labyrinth, no shelter;
6.\nHere, beneath an ancient throne, small comfort.
7.\nInto the dust of the road, the dusk must burrow. From crag to creekside and past all points beyond, the evening falls.
8.\nNight gathers where the flamekin wail, its fingers at their throats. Our compact with the darkness was for nothing.

9.\nOne day, the day will find its furthest limit, the place beyond which no days are imagined: a place long sealed away, lost within the endless mountain range. One day, the night will find this place, and breach it.
10.\nOn that day, then, the night will come to Lorwyn.\n—Narvek Riag, kithkin prophet
